speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 15-420, United States v. Bryant. Ms. Prelogar.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose you had a conviction from a foreign country. Would that --  could that be used for this purpose, assuming the statute allowed it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Would there be a due process problem? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why more serious --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: --  in England?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could that showing be attempted in a case like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I --  are foreign judgments --  are foreign convictions --  I thought it had to be a Federal, State or a tribal court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm assuming the statute was amended.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's certainly rendered outside the Constitution.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So this case would come out differently if Congress had not enacted the Indian Civil Rights Act?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what if they -- what if they had? In other words, convictions in a tribal court do count as predicates, and there is no Indian Civil Rights Act.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So it would be a case-by-case determination?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We already do that, don't we, in the career armed felony statute because we permit reliance on foreign convictions, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So that we already put in play the issue of whether an individual in a foreign proceeding follows due process or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And this due process is not raised in this case at all, right --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- by Respondent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If he hasn't raised it here, are you suggesting by reserving it in this case, that on remand, that issue could be aired?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell me just as a matter of practice, if you know, are these claims of -- of unfairness in individual tribes made often or in recent years, in cases like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I just don't know.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers had discussion of a few prosecutions where those claims were raised.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but how would that work in a case like this? I mean, let's say there are procedural deficiencies in one of the predicate prosecutions. And, you know, the defendant says, okay, well, it was a misdemeanor. He --  he doesn't seem to be terribly troubled by convictions, anyway, but --  so he says, I'm not going to seek review of that. But then later on, the prosecution comes along. Is he just sort of stuck with the prior allegedly deficient prosecution because he didn't bring every challenge he possibly could have at that time?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, maybe he didn't have any --  maybe he didn't have any reason to challenge it. I mean, my hypothetical assumes a --  a predicate offense conviction that the defendant may not have challenged for whatever reason. And yet when the --  if I've got the numbers right --  action comes up, it turns out it's a lot more serious, which often happens in these multiple offenders. You know, it's Alderson Reporting Company three -- three strikes and you get it. But you don't necessarily know that the first strike was that -- that big a deal. It's only when it's accumulated with the others that it is.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I don't -- I -- I saw that argument in -- in your brief, and I'm not sure I'm quite -- well, I'm not sure I agree with it. I mean, the -- the idea you're saying is that, well, if there's three offenses and on the third one, you get this much enhanced penalty, that that's only for the third one. It doesn't -- it's not being imposed for the prior two. I mean, I understand that, that you're already been convicted and sentenced under the prior two, but it seems to me as a practical matter it's fair to say that the enhancement is based on those prior two. You can't just ignore the prior two and say, no, no, it's all just about this third offense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Bryant makes --  makes a distinction between a sentence enhancement on the one hand and the case where the prior conviction counts as an element of the current offense. Would you address what that argument was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the proof would be simply submitting, I suppose, a certified copy of the judgment of conviction. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Should there be distinctions between prior, A, acts; B, convictions, that in one case would result in a -- the commission of a crime, and in another case, just enhance the sentence? Should there ever be a distinction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could you use the existence of a civil judgment for domestic assault to enhance a criminal sentence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay. And then you could use a previous criminal -- a previous civil adjudication for domestic assault as the basis for a Federal crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's a very extensive -- that's a very extensive argument you're making.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do we know why -- why Congress, in the Indian Civil Rights Act, made the right to counsel narrower than the right in the Sixth Amendment?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So -- so they knew better than Madison?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Madison -- the drafters of the bill, they thought, well, maybe the right to counsel was necessary here but Congress think it's not that necessary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The tribal -- there was a limit -- I think has been raised -- there is a limit on the punishment, the incarceration that a tribal court could order. I think it was -- wasn't it originally one year?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: One year, and now it's three years?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Babcock.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you do --  disagree with --  I think Ms. Prelogar said that you --  you acknowledged that if the only sentence had been a fine, no jail time, that these --  these two prior battery misdemeanors, if the --  the tribal court gave only a fine and no jail time, then those convictions could be used under for a prosecution.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry. I -- I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: My thought is this is quite formalistic. It doesn't have anything to do with inherent reliability or unreliability. In fact, if it were an uncounseled felony conviction, it might well have been that the trial judge was much more careful Alderson Reporting Company than he would be in a misdemeanor case. It's almost the opposite. I --  I understand your --  the efficacy of the clear line, but it's more formalistic than functional, it does seem to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But as Justice Ginsburg pointed out, you could make the same argument if it had been just a fine and no Sixth Amendment violation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So I don't understand why Alderson Reporting Company one is reliable and the other is not reliable, other than the formalistic argument which I can understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But did anybody object at that time and say this sentence is unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. But, I mean, is anybody here now claiming that the sentence was unconstitutional at the time?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You have? Where did you say that in your brief? Because they say you didn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. I'm saying in your Alderson Reporting Company brief in this Court, have you claimed that the sentence, the proceeding in the Indian court violated the Federal Constitution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. Well, then, I take it that for purposes here, you concede that. I don't see how you can get around the fact you haven't complained. So if it's a valid conviction, why can't you use it? I mean, you could --  you could sentence people to more; that's what Nichols says. You could sentence them to three times the sentence without any conviction. You would just introduce some evidence that he hit his wife before badly. You could --  you could raise the sentence if it was a civil --  if it was a civil case. And --  and there was a judgment in favor of the wife, I take it. So why can't you raise the sentence on the ground that there is a valid conviction, period? End of the case. Which is, I think, what Nichols said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah. But you have told me that you have not --  I don't see how you could send a Alderson Reporting Company person to prison on the basis of the -- the lack -- where there's no counsel. If the Indian tribes can do that, then I don't see why the Federal government can't later use it if that's valid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then we should hold that -- I guess, that all of the convictions in all the tribes that are using, going to jail where people might go to prison for more than six months or at all, for a day, all those are invalid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then the law of Congress is unconstitutional. Is that -- is that -- but no one's asked us to hold that, so I don't know that we should hold that in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's the question, which is: Standing alone, was that earlier conviction violative of the Constitution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right. And so you're not challenging that the Bill of Rights do not apply -- because we've long held that -- don't apply to Indian courts, correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: They don't apply to English courts --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- and other foreign courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And there are plenty of foreign courts, like England for a time -- I think it's changing it now -- where they would convict people after a magisterial inquisition where the defendant didn't have counsel. You're not saying that process violates the Constitution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're saying simply because we're using that conviction, we now violated. Why? Nichols, as I understand it, had two rationales: One that says using a prior constitutional Alderson Reporting Company conviction, one that doesn't violate the Constitution, is not enhancing a sentence, is not changing that earlier conviction. It's not enhancing a sentence for that earlier conviction, so you can use it, because it's just setting the platform for the current punishment, for the conduct now. How does your argument -- why does your argument change that rationale?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, we -- Nichols itself said enhancement statutes, whether in the nature of criminal history provisions, such as those contained in the Sentencing Guidelines, or recidivist statutes that are commonplace in State criminal law, those recidivist statutes make prior convictions an element, do not change the penalty imposed for an earlier conviction. That's what Nichols said. So the Nichols rationale covered both.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Covered sentencing guidelines and covered recidivist statutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Nichols said that's okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, it says it was relying on recidivist statutes that are commonplace in State criminal laws.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right. And those make them an element of the crime.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's the second prong of Nichols.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But isn't that a due process argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I can see --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: --  the distinction between --  that you made between beyond a reasonable doubt and preponderance of the evidence, but practically, I mean, what's involved here is proof of a conviction entered by a court. And so you --  you Alderson Reporting Company present the certified copy of the judgment, and that's it. That satisfies proof beyond a reasonable doubt.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What are the -- the cases both Justice Kennedy and Justice Scalia suggested that in -- not in this statute, but there are criminal Alderson Reporting Company statutes that allow the use of a foreign conviction to count for recidivism purposes, for -- for a variety of purposes. And many of our partners in the world don't have the same -- same rights as -- that are in our Bill of Rights, and yet we -- we credit those convictions.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Prelogar, eight minutes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
